                    <h1 class="page-header" itemprop="name">12-Year-Old Mexican 'Scientist' Hilariously Proves Vaccines Don't Cause Autism</h1>
                  
            
                          
            
      <div  itemprop="description">
<article id="node-92497" class="node node-article clearfix">


  <header>
            
          <span class="submitted">
                By <span itemprop="author"><a href="/author/raquel-reichard" title="View user profile." class="username">Raquel Reichard</a></span> •  <span itemprop="dateCreated">June 1, 2016</span> •  10:37am       </span>
      </header>

  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item even"><p><iframe allowfullscreen="true" allowtransparency="true" frameborder="0" height="315" scrolling="no" src="https://www.facebook.com/plugins/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2F224110424640151%2Fvideos%2Fvb.224110424640151%2F224150204636173%2F%3Ftype%3D3&show_text=0&width=560" style="border:none;overflow:hidden" width="560"></iframe></p><p>Mexicano <strong>Marco Arturo</strong> is winning the Internet. The 12-year-old science lover posted a video on Facebook for his thousands of followers last week, as he does usually. But this time, his smart and hilarious short vid on a contentious topic is blowing up – for all the right reasons.</p><p>Arturo completed a lengthy investigation that links vaccines to autism, and he wants to share "every single bit of evidence that is in the observable universe that vaccines do causes autism" with his viewers. All the proof is in a folder, but when he opens it to school the world, he finds that all the papers are blank, helping him come to an important conclusion.</p><p>“I think it might be because there is absolutely no evidence to support the statement that vaccines are linked to autism in any way whatsoever,” the young boy brilliantly says before encouraging parents to stop believing inaccurate chain emails they’ve been forwarded and vaccinate their kiddies to keep them, and those around them, safe from diseases like measles, meningitis and polio.</p><p><a href="http://www.latina.com/lifestyle/health/anti-vaccination-debate-facts" target="_blank">MORE: Everything You Need to Wrap Your Head Around the Vaccination Debate</a></p><p>Watch the vid, which has been shared by more than 63 thousand Fb users (including <strong>Ashton Kutcher</strong>), above.</p>
</div>
      </div>
</div><div id="adg_main"></div><div class="field field-name-field-share-this field-type-addthis field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Share this </div><div class="field-items"><section id="block-block-24" class="block block-block clearfix">

      
  <div class="addthis_jumbo_share"></div>  
</section> <!-- /.block -->
</div></div>      <footer>
